results.title: Emulation of Team Fortress for PC
results.creator_credit: Ian Caughley, John Cook, Robin Walker and Team Fortress Software
results.brief_description:
Team Fortress is a team and class-based multiplayer online first-person shooter video game mod based on id Software’s Quake Engine. The game has two teams battling it out in game modes like territorial control, capture the flag and escorting a VIP. A high degree of teamwork and cooperation is required to achieve these goals. This is embodied by the game’s class system. A player has a choice of nine different classes to play, each with its own strengths, weaknesses and skills that complement the other classes.

Due to its success, the developers were hired by Valve to mod it for their own game, Half-Life. This eventually led to a series of tweaks, enhancements and additions to the base game, eventually releasing as a standalone version titled Team Fortress Classic.

results.title: Magnavox Odyssey console
results.material_description: Video game console functioning as a playable unit. Also includes original box with contents
results.brief_description: Modified Odyssey video game console with original packaging, original contents and two controllers
results.description:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

The Magnavox Odyssey was released in 1972. Players controlled two dots while the console controlled another that darted around the screen and could be returned like the ball in pong. Though the basic gameplay was the same, people could put graphic overlays over their TV to create different game experiences, like skiing and football.
description_for_label:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

The Magnavox Odyssey was released in 1972. Players controlled two dots while the console controlled another that darted around the screen and could be returned like the ball in pong. Though the basic gameplay was the same, people could put graphic overlays over their TV to create different game experiences, like skiing and football.

results.title: Bernice bobs her hair
results.creator_credit: Joan Micklin Silver, Paul R. Gurian and Perspective Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The American Short Story”.
A young flapper bobs her hair to gain peer approval but she learns a lesson in values. An adaptation of the short story of the same title by F. Scott Fitzgerald.

results.title: Warlords III: Reign of Heroes for PC
results.creator_credit: Red Orb Entertainment and Strategic Studies Group
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case, advert, card game advert, registration card, troubleshooting guide, internet guide and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: The third instalment in the Warlords series boasts improved graphics throughout and retains much of the same turn-based strategy gameplay as its predecessors. The units a player can train are now not set to a specific clan, as new types of units from different clans can join the player’s faction. Also new to the series is the addition of diplomacy, where a player can forge treaties with others and conquer opponents together. This includes the ability to bribe others in order to influence their decisions. Lastly, while the game still allows for hotseat and play by email multiplayer, it now has the ability to play over the internet.

results.title: Warlords: Battlecry for PC
results.creator_credit: Strategic Simulations, Inc. and Strategic Studies Group
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case, CD case insert, reference card, epilepsy warning sheet, advert and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: As part of the Warlords series, Warlords Battlecry retains the fantasy setting and tactical focus of its predecessors. However, if shifts from the wargame genre that the series is known for to a mix of real-time strategy and roleplaying. The players commands one of nine races – Human, Dwarf, Undead, Barbarians, Orcs, Minotaurs, High Elves, Wood Elves and Dark Elves. True to real-time strategy genre, buildings must be created, units trained, upgrades researched and resources gathered. Unique to this game is the addition of hero units, which can complete quests and gain experience, strength and skills, unlike the other units in their army.

results.title: Reach for the Stars for PC
results.creator_credit: Strategic Simulations, Inc. and Strategic Studies Group
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD case insert, CD jewel case, licence agreement and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Reach for the Stars is a re-released and updated version of the DOS era game of the same name, the earliest example of a game in the 4X genre. The player starts off in a single planetary system and must eventually create and run an interstellar empire. In typical 4X style, this is done by exploring the universe around the player, expanding by claiming new territory, exploiting any resources in the area and exterminating any opponents along the way. The re-release features updated graphics and new scenarios for the player.

results.title: Krazy Ivan for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case, manual and registration card in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aliens have invaded the earth, raised energy generators that are slowly engulfing the planet and have imprisoned humans in robots. The only person who can stop them is Russian Commander Ivan Popovich and his Steel Cossack, a battle-ready powersuit.

In this 3D first person arcade shooter, the player must destroy the five energy generators by defeating the aliens defending it while simultaneously freeing any humans in the process. Rescuing humans gives the player resources that can be used to upgrade the Steel Cossack.

results.title: Touring Car Champions for DOS
results.creator_credit: Virtual Sports Interactive and Torus Games
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Touring Car Champions is based on the Australian Touring Car Championship and the Bathurst 1000. The game features only one track, set in Bathurst, New South Wales. Interestingly, this is depicted through full motion video of the actual track, instead of being recreated or rendered in within the game itself. The video slows down or speeds up based on the player’s speed and the opponent’s cars are 3D models superimposed onto this video.

The game features three modes: The first is Practice, which has no opponents. Quick Race has the player choosing the difficulty of the opponents and racing in a pre-set car. Lastly, The Round is a season-spanning tournament where the player has to work their way up from the amateur division to eventual Touring Car Champion. Along the way, the player can decide what racers, pit crew and car parts to use in each race.

results.title: Dirt Track Racing for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD envelope, install instructions in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Dirt Track Racing, the player controls a vehicle in a race around oval or figure-eight dirt tracks. The game features three classes of cars - stock, pro stock, and late model - which can be enhanced with high performance parts. The game allows you to either play one race or go through a career mode where the player starts with next to nothing and slowly accumulates more money and better cars through winning races and gaining sponsors. The player can also race up to 10 people online.

results.title: The Lost World Jurassic Park for Game Boy
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge case, consumer information booklet, Nintendo Power subscription form, registration card, poster and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Based on the movie of the same name, The Lost World: Jurassic Park is set on Isla Sorna, also known as “Site B”, where dinosaurs were created to populate the original park. As an agent for InGen, the player must recover eggs, DNA and key information on the cloning process before BioSyn, a rival company, gets their hands on it. Gameplay consists of running, jumping and climbing through the buildings, jungles and caves of the island. Getting in the player’s way are BioSyn thugs and a variety of dinosaurs, such as Pterodactyl, Triceratops and the eponymous Tyrannosaurus Rex. The player can defend himself by using kicks, punches and weapons, as well as ammo and health power-ups.
